terracotta_hedgehog.physical_characteristics: Medium mushroom with terracotta to orange-brown cap 3-10cm across. Cap smooth, often irregular. Underside has short, fragile spines rather than gills. Stem central or off-center, similarly colored. Flesh white and firm.
terracotta_hedgehog.look_alike: Similar to the larger Hedgehog Mushroom (Hydnum repandum) which is paler colored. Both are edible. Distinguished by its smaller size and warmer terracotta coloration.
terracotta_hedgehog.usages: Excellent culinary mushroom with firm texture and mild, nutty flavor. Doesn't require extensive cleaning as no gills to trap debris. Good sautéed or in soups.
terracotta_hedgehog.safety_tips: One of the safest wild mushrooms to identify due to the distinctive spines. Clean gently as spines are fragile. Cook before eating. No poisonous look-alikes with spines.

basic_info.edibility: Choice edible with excellent flavor. One of the best Agaricus species. Strong almond/aniseed aroma.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in woodlands, parks, and gardens. Often found under conifers. Appears in late summer and autumn.

the_prince.physical_characteristics: Large, impressive mushroom with scaly brown cap on yellow background. Cap 10-25cm, spherical then expanding. Gills pale then chocolate brown. Stem has large, hanging ring. Strong almond/aniseed smell.
the_prince.look_alike: Similar to other Agaricus species but much larger. The Yellow Stainer stains bright yellow and has chemical smell. The strong almond aroma and large size are characteristic.
the_prince.usages: Excellent culinary mushroom - can be used in any mushroom recipe. The strong flavor holds up well in cooking. Popular among experienced foragers.
the_prince.safety_tips: Check for yellow staining - should not stain bright yellow instantly. The almond smell is a good identifier. Only collect from clean areas. Cook thoroughly.

basic_info.edibility: Poisonous. Causes vomiting and gastrointestinal distress. The common name clearly indicates its effects.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in coniferous and mixed woodlands. Mycorrhizal with various trees. Common in mossy areas. Found in summer and autumn.

the_sickener.physical_characteristics: Medium Russula with bright red cap that fades with age. Cap 5-10cm, convex then depressed. Gills white. Stem white. Flesh white and brittle with extremely hot, peppery taste.
the_sickener.look_alike: Similar to other red-capped Russula species. The edible Beechwood Sickener has different habitat and milder taste. The extremely hot taste is a key identifier.
the_sickener.usages: No safe uses. The hot taste makes it unpalatable anyway. Sometimes used in traditional medicine in very small doses but not recommended.
the_sickener.safety_tips: Taste test Russula species (spit out immediately) - any with extremely hot, peppery taste should be avoided. The bright red color is a warning sign.

basic_info.edibility: Choice edible with good flavor. Cultivated as Enoki mushroom. Can be found in winter.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in clusters on dead and dying hardwood trees, particularly elm. Appears in autumn and can be found throughout winter.

velvet_shank.physical_characteristics: Small to medium mushroom growing in dense clusters. Cap 2-8cm, orange to yellow-brown, sticky when moist. Gills pale yellow. Stem dark velvety brown, particularly at base. Can survive freezing temperatures.
velvet_shank.look_alike: Similar to other winter-growing fungi. The cultivated Enoki is the same species but looks different due to growing conditions. The velvet stem and winter growth are characteristic.
velvet_shank.usages: Excellent culinary mushroom with good flavor. The wild form has more flavor than cultivated Enoki. Good in soups and stir-fries. Can be found when other mushrooms are unavailable.
velvet_shank.safety_tips: Only collect from hardwoods. Clean thoroughly as the sticky cap traps debris. Cook before eating. One of the safest winter mushrooms to identify.

basic_info.edibility: Edibility disputed - best avoided. Similar to poisonous Panther Cap and may contain toxins.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in deciduous and coniferous woodlands. Mycorrhizal with various trees. Found in summer and autumn.

warted_amanita.physical_characteristics: Medium Amanita with gray-brown cap covered in grayish warts. Cap 5-15cm. White gills. Stem white with ring and bulbous base with volva. Smells of radish or potatoes.
warted_amanita.look_alike: Very similar to the deadly Panther Cap. Distinguished by grayer warts and less defined volva, but these differences are subtle and unreliable for beginners.
warted_amanita.usages: Not recommended for consumption due to similarity with poisonous species and uncertain edibility. Best left alone.
warted_amanita.safety_tips: Avoid all Amanitas with warty caps and volvas unless you are an expert. The similarities between edible and deadly species are too close for safe consumption by amateurs.

basic_info.edibility: Poisonous. Causes severe gastrointestinal distress. Raw consumption is particularly dangerous.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in birch woodlands. Mycorrhizal with birch trees. Common in summer and autumn.

woolly_milkcap.physical_characteristics: Medium milkcap with pink to orange-pink cap that has distinctive hairy or woolly margin. Cap 5-15cm. When cut, exudes white milk that is extremely acrid. Gills pale pink.
woolly_milkcap.look_alike: Similar to other pink milkcaps but the woolly cap margin is characteristic. The edible Saffron Milkcap has different colors and mild-tasting milk.
woolly_milkcap.usages: No safe uses. The extremely acrid milk makes it unpalatable. Sometimes used in dyeing for its colors.
woolly_milkcap.safety_tips: Avoid all milkcaps with hairy cap margins. The acrid taste of the milk (spit test) is a clear warning sign. Only collect milkcaps with mild-tasting milk.

basic_info.edibility: Choice edible with excellent flavor. One of the most highly prized wild mushrooms. Must be cooked thoroughly.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in various habitats including woodlands, orchards, and disturbed ground. Often found under ash, elm, and apple trees. Appears in spring.

yellow_morel.physical_characteristics: Distinctive honeycombed mushroom with yellow to tan cap. Cap 5-15cm tall, pitted with irregular ridges and pits. Entire mushroom hollow. Stem white to cream, granular texture.
yellow_morel.look_alike: Similar to other morel species. False morels have brain-like rather than honeycomb appearance and are not completely hollow. The honeycomb pattern and hollow interior are key identifiers.
yellow_morel.usages: Highly prized culinary mushroom with rich, earthy flavor. Must be cooked thoroughly - never eat raw. Excellent sautéed, in sauces, or dried. Gourmet ingredient.
yellow_morel.safety_tips: Always cook thoroughly to destroy heat-sensitive toxins. Learn to distinguish from false morels - true morels are completely hollow. Clean thoroughly as insects hide in pits.

basic_info.edibility: Inedible. Tough, gelatinous texture and no culinary value. Not poisonous but unpalatable.
basic_info.habitat: Grows on conifer wood, particularly pine stumps and logs. Appears in autumn and can persist through winter.

yellow_stagshorn.physical_characteristics: Bright yellow to orange, branching coral-like fungus. Branches 3-8cm tall, antler-shaped with pointed tips. Gelatinous but firm texture. Grows in groups on wood.
yellow_stagshorn.look_alike: Similar to other coral fungi but the bright yellow color and growth on conifer wood are characteristic. The edible Yellow Coral (Ramaria species) grows on ground and has different branching pattern.
yellow_stagshorn.usages: No culinary uses due to tough texture. Sometimes used in decorative arrangements or photography due to attractive color and shape.
yellow_stagshorn.safety_tips: Not worth foraging for food. While not poisonous, the texture is unpalatable. Appreciate for its ornamental value in woodland settings.

basic_info.edibility: Poisonous. Causes gastrointestinal distress in most people. Common cause of mushroom poisoning.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in grasslands, parks, and woodlands. Often found in urban areas. Appears in summer and autumn, sometimes in large groups.

yellow_stainer.physical_characteristics: Medium Agaricus with white cap that stains bright chrome yellow when bruised, particularly at base of stem. Cap 5-15cm. Has unpleasant chemical or ink-like smell. Gills pale then pinkish.
yellow_stainer.look_alike: Often confused with edible field mushrooms and horse mushrooms. The instant bright yellow staining and chemical smell are key identifiers. The staining is most obvious at stem base.
yellow_stainer.usages: No safe uses. The unpleasant smell and toxic properties make it unsuitable for any use. Sometimes used in identification courses to demonstrate staining reaction.
yellow_stainer.safety_tips: Always check for yellow staining by rubbing the base of the stem. Avoid any with chemical smell. The yellow staining is instant and bright, unlike the slow yellowing of edible species.

basic_info.edibility: Edible when properly identified and cooked. Considered a good edible mushroom by experienced foragers.
basic_info.habitat: Found in woodland areas, particularly under oak trees. Mycorrhizal relationship with hardwoods. Appears in spring, often after rains.

yellow_veiled_amanita.physical_characteristics: Medium-sized Amanita with pale yellow to orange-yellow cap. Cap 5-15cm across, smooth with striate margin. Lacks the prominent warts of many Amanitas. Stem is white to pale yellow with fragile ring and sac-like volva at base. Flesh is white with mild odor.
yellow_veiled_amanita.look_alike: Similar to other yellow-capped Amanitas, including some poisonous species. The lack of warts and striate cap margin help identification. Could be confused with deadly Amanita species by beginners.
yellow_veiled_amanita.usages: Good culinary mushroom when properly identified. Must be cooked thoroughly. Popular among experienced forasers in California and western North America. Can be used in various cooked dishes.
yellow_veiled_amanita.safety_tips: Only for experienced mushroom identifiers familiar with Amanita species. Always check for volva at base. Cook thoroughly before eating. When in doubt, avoid all Amanitas due to similarity with deadly species.

basic_info.edibility: Excellent edible with good flavor. Also known as Winter Chanterelle. Keeps well when dried.
basic_info.habitat: Grows in mossy coniferous woodlands, particularly in damp areas. Often found in large troops. Appears in autumn and can persist into winter.

yellowfoot.physical_characteristics: Small, funnel-shaped mushroom with brown to yellow-brown cap and distinctive yellow stem. Cap 2-6cm, often with central depression. Underside has fold-like false gills. Hollow stem. Grows in groups.
yellowfoot.look_alike: Similar to other chanterelles but smaller and with hollow stem. The edible Horn of Plenty is larger and black. The yellow stem and winter growth are characteristic.
yellowfoot.usages: Excellent culinary mushroom with good flavor. Popular in European cuisine. Excellent when dried - flavor intensifies. Good in soups, sauces, and mixed dishes.
yellowfoot.safety_tips: One of the safer wild mushrooms to identify. The false gills and hollow stem are good identifiers. Clean thoroughly as small size traps debris. Cook before eating.
